text: Welcome back to our channel. But don't
just scroll away.
Because what you're about to hear is not
just a business story. This is a life
story.
A story of a boy who grew up in pain,
who watched his father suffer, who lived
in broken apartments and walked through
life feeling invisible.
And yet he went on to build one of the
most loved brands on earth. Not just a
coffee shop, but a brand that changed
how the world starts its day. And no, he
wasn't born rich. No, he didn't have
connections. No, he didn't even found
the company he would one day transform.
He was laughed at, rejected, and told.
No one will ever pay $3 for a cup of
coffee. He heard no not once, not 10
times, but 217 times. And still he did
it. His name is Howard Schultz. And this
is the story of how he turned a painful
childhood into a billion dollar brand.
How he transformed coffee into culture,
and how rejection became the fuel that
made him unstoppable.
And yes, while you listen, you're also
improving your English because we use
clear, emotional, beginnerfriendly
storytelling that helps you learn new
words, real life lessons, and become
fluent through stories. So, grab your
coffee or your dreams because this isn't
just a story you'll remember. This is a
story that might change your life. Part
one. The boy who grew up in Japan,
Brooklyn, New York, 1953.
Howard Schulz was born into a world
where dreams were small because life was
hard.
He grew up in the Bay View housing
projects, a government housing project
in a rough Brooklyn neighborhood where
people survived paycheck to paycheck.
His father was a delivery driver. No big
job, no stability, no health insurance.
One day he slipped on ice and injured
his hip badly. And you know what
happened? Nothing. No medical help, no
compensation, no support, no voice.
Howard watched his father, a strong man,
become broken and hopeless overnight. He
watched him sit on the couch, jobless,
depressed, and filled with shame. There
was no one to help, no one to care.
Howard would later say, "That moment
changed me. I saw what it meant to be a
number, not a person. I promised myself
if I ever built a company, it would
honor people, not crush them. He was
just a boy." But that pain stayed in his
soul. They were so poor, Howard used to
feel embarrassed to bring friends home.
He had no room of his own, no luxury,
not even enough clothes sometimes.
He said, "When you're that poor, you
never forget it. Poverty leaves a
shadow."
But this shadow didn't kill him. It lit
a fire inside him. Howard had no path
laid out for success. But he had one
superpower, determination. He played
sports. He worked odd jobs. He sold
newspapers. He saved money. And against
all odds, he became the first in his
family to go to college. But even that
wasn't easy. He didn't go to Harvard. He
went to Northern Michigan University on
a football scholarship and worked as a
bartender and salesman to pay for
school.
After college, he started working as a
salesman for Xerox, one of the best
sales training companies at that time.
He was good, very good. But Howard
wanted more.
One day, he joined a small kitchen wear
company. His job, sell coffee machines
to local cafes. And that's when
something unexpected happened.
While analyzing sales reports, he
noticed one small client in Seattle kept
buying more machines than anyone else.
He was curious, so he flew there to find
out why. The company was called
Starbucks. At that time, it had just
four stores, and it didn't even sell
coffee to drink, just beans, grinders,
and equipment. But there was something
about the people, the energy, the
philosophy.
Howard fell in love. He said, "There was
something magical about Starbucks. I saw
more than coffee. I saw warmth,
authenticity, culture." And in that
moment, a seed was planted. He quit his
job. He joined Starbucks, but he had no
idea that this small decision would lead
to the biggest battle of his life.
Howard Schultz had seen pain. He had
felt invisible. He had been poor,
hopeless, and humiliated.
But he also had a dream
to build something better than what his
father had. To build a company that
respected people. And he had just found
the perfect soil. Starbucks. What he
didn't know yet was that the very people
he admired would soon turn down his
biggest idea. They would say, "That's
not who we are."
But Howard Schultz was no ordinary man.
He didn't just sell coffee. He was about
to sell a new way of life. Howard
Schultz had joined Starbucks, a small
company in Seattle. He was not the
owner. He was not rich. He was just an
employee. But inside him, something
bigger was growing. A vision that nobody
else could see. In 1983, Starbucks sent
Howard to Milan, Italy for a trade show.
It was supposed to be a short business
trip, but what he discovered there
changed the direction of his life. As he
walked through the streets of Milan,
something caught his heart. There were
espresso bars on every corner, busy,
vibrant, full of people. But they
weren't just drinking coffee. They were
talking, laughing, sharing moments,
connecting. The barista knew people by
name. Customers didn't just come for
coffee. They came for experience,
emotion, community.
Howard stood there, speechless. It was
like stepping into a new world.
This is it, he thought. This is what
America doesn't have. We don't have this
culture, this experience, this feeling.
He didn't see coffee. He saw warmth. He
saw belonging. He saw something human.
When he returned to Seattle, Howard
walked into the Starbucks office on fire
with excitement.
He told the founders,
"We need to open coffee bars, not just
sell beans. Let people drink the coffee
here. Let's create that Italian espresso
culture right here in America."
He was excited. He was confident. He was
ready to build something new. But then
came the answer that broke him. The
founders of Starbucks, Jerry Baldwin,
Zev Seagull, and Gordon Baler, listened
quietly.
Then they said, "No, that's not who we
are. We sell coffee beans, not serve
drinks."
They didn't believe Americans would ever
go for it. They thought people wouldn't
pay $2 or $3 for a cup of coffee. They
thought it was too risky, too strange.
Howard was stunned. This was his moment,
his dream, his mission, and it was
crushed. Howard didn't argue, he didn't
scream, but inside he knew. If they
won't do it, I have to do it myself.
And so, with nothing but belief, Howard
made the biggest decision of his life.
He would leave Starbucks to start his
own coffee bar. Howard was heartbroken.
He loved Starbucks, but his dream was
bigger than loyalty. So in 1985 he quit.
He decided to start a company called
Iljouali named after an Italian
newspaper. But he had no money. He had
to raise funds to start. Howard believed
in his idea. He thought investors would
too. But what happened? Rejection.
After rejection. After rejection. He
would walk into meetings full of passion
and walk out with closed doors.
Americans won't pay $3 for coffee.
You're not Italian. This won't work
here. You're dreaming too big. He was
laughed at, ignored, and insulted. He
said, "I was rejected 200 MSN teen
times. That number is burned into my
brain." But he kept going day after day,
meeting after meeting, pitch after
pitch, until finally
30 investors said yes, he raised
and in 1986 opened his first coffee bar
in Seattle. It wasn't just a coffee
shop, it was a love letter to Italy.
Howard made sure everything felt
different. Italian music played softly
in the background.
Baristas remembered your name. You
didn't just buy coffee. You had an
experience.
And guess what? People loved it. They
didn't care that it was new. They didn't
care about the price. They came for the
feeling. Iljornal became an instant hit.
Howard proved them wrong. While Iljali
was booming, something unexpected
happened. The founders of Starbucks, the
very people who said no, decided to sell
the company. They were moving on.
Starbucks was too small for them now.
Howard saw a chance. A big one. A
dangerous one. A dream that had once
been denied to him was now up for sale.
But there was a problem. In 1987, Howard
found out the price.
To buy Starbucks, he needed 3.8 million.
That's about 10 million today. And
Howard didn't have that kind of money.
He was still small, still building. But
this wasn't just a business move for
him. This was personal. This was his
dream. So once again, he went back into
battle. He talked to every investor he
could find. He begged, he pitched, he
cried, he told them, "This is not just a
coffee company. This is my life's
purpose.
Finally, after weeks of effort, he
raised the money. And in August 1987, at
age 34, Howard Schultz bought Starbucks
for $3.8 million. And he didn't just buy
the company, he bought back his vision.
Part two, the coffee that became a
culture. It was 1987.
Howard had just bought Starbucks. But
what did he actually buy? It wasn't a
global brand. It wasn't profitable. It
wasn't even a proper cafe.
All it had was six stores, a small
roasting plant, a confused brand
identity, and a few dozen employees.
The company did not serve coffee to
drink. It only sold coffee beans,
machines, and accessories.
There were no lattes, no cappuccinos, no
frappuccinos, and no music. Nothing you
recognize today existed yet. Howard had
a mountain to climb. Howard didn't just
want to own Starbucks. He wanted to
reinvent it. His mission was clear.
Starbucks will not just sell coffee. It
will sell an experience, a feeling, a
third place between work and home. So he
got to work. Howard had three key
principles. One, create a human
connection. Customers should feel seen,
valued, and respected. Two, design
stores with emotion. Each store would be
warm, inviting with soft lighting,
music, and a unique smell.
Three, make every cup feel personal. The
baristas would remember names, smile,
and make you feel like family. He didn't
want to sell fast coffee. He wanted to
build ritual, emotion, and community,
just like he saw in Italy.
Howard focused on tiny things that other
businesses ignored. The smell inside the
store. Never let food overpower the
smell of coffee. The music. Every
Starbucks had curated playlists to match
the mood. The seating, cozy, not
cramped. The counters designed so
baristas and customers could talk
comfortably. The lighting always soft,
never harsh. The names on cups to make
every customer feel special. And most
importantly,
the person behind the counter is not
just making coffee. They are creating
warmth. Howard believed the employees
were the heart of the brand. He didn't
call them staff or workers. He called
them partners. Even part-time baristas
were given healthc care benefits, stock
options, training, not just for skill,
but for soul. This was revolutionary in
America, especially for a coffee shop.
Howard said, "If we treat our people
well, they will treat our customers
well, and everything will take care of
itself."
He made sure baristas, looked customers
in the eye, smiled, asked how your day
was, remembered regulars. In Starbucks,
you were not a number. You were a name,
a person, a story. In 1987, after Howard
took over, Starbucks had just six
stores, no national presence, a huge
vision, but very little profit. Over the
next 5 years, he grew Starbucks to 165
stores across cities like Chicago,
Vancouver, and New York. But this growth
wasn't random. Every location was
carefully picked. Every store was
designed to create community, not just
sell coffee. Howard refused to franchise
the stores.
Why? Because he wanted to protect the
experience. He said, "I want to control
the quality, the emotion, the feeling
that can't be outsourced." Before
Starbucks, most Americans had never
heard of espresso, latte, cappuccino,
macchiato, frappuccino.
Howard made these words part of everyday
life. He trained his staff and customers
to learn them patiently and
respectfully. And slowly the culture
changed.
People didn't just say coffee. They
said, "Can I get a tall vanilla latte
with soy milk? Starbucks didn't just
sell drinks." It educated, uplifted, and
reshaped how people thought about their
daily routine.
Howard knew the power of branding.
He didn't want just a good cup of
coffee. He wanted customers to feel
proud holding a Starbucks cup. So they
invested heavily in clean minimalist
logo design, highquality cup materials,
consistent green and white branding, a
sense of premium experience. Very soon,
holding a Starbucks cup became a
statement. I'm successful. I have taste.
I take care of myself. This is my time.
Howard realized something deep.
People aren't just buying coffee.
They're buying a moment of peace, a
sense of belonging, a way to feel seen.
And that's exactly what he gave them.
For a few dollars, three, four, five,
people didn't just get a drink. They got
a cozy seat, calm music, friendly
conversation, a small break from the
chaos of life. And that was priceless.
By the early 1990s, Starbucks had
expanded to several major US cities. It
was earning millions in revenue.
Customer loyalty was extremely high. The
brand was now seen as modern, classy,
and cool. People went to Starbucks to
read, to write, to have meetings, to
fall in love, to take a break, to feel
human. By the early 1990s, Starbucks was
no longer just a Seattle brand. It had
become a national sensation. The coffee
shop was a cultural icon, a lifestyle
statement, a business case study, and a
morning ritual for millions.
But Howard was not satisfied. He wasn't
thinking about 100 stores. He was
thinking 10,000.
He wanted to take Starbucks to Europe,
Asia, every airport, every corner of
every city. And to do that, he needed
serious capital.
In 1992, Starbucks went public on the
NASDAQ stock exchange. Ticker symbol
SPX. Stock price $17 per share. Initial
valuation around $250 million. Howard
Schultz once rejected 217 times. now had
built a company that Wall Street wanted
to own. The IPO was a massive success.
Starbucks stock skyrocketed in the first
year. With fresh funding, Howard had the
fuel he needed to expand faster than
ever before. While Starbucks was
expanding, something unexpected
happened. In 1994, in Santa Monica,
California, a small group of Starbucks
baristas noticed something. Customers
were asking for cold blended coffee
drinks at the time. Starbucks had no
cold coffee menu. But these baristas
didn't wait for approval. They
experimented. They blended espresso with
ice, milk, chocolate, whipped cream, and
created something new. When Howard found
out, he didn't punish them. He didn't
say, "That's not in the manual."
Instead, he tasted the drink and smiled.
"This is brilliant," he said. "We're
launching it nationwide."
In 1995, Starbucks officially launched
the Frappuccino.
It became an instant sensation,
especially with younger customers. In
its first full year, Frappuccino
generated over $50 million in revenue.
It wasn't part of the original plan, but
it became one of Starbucks's most
successful products of all time. With
momentum building in the US, Howard now
looked beyond American borders. His
first international target, Tokyo,
Japan. Why Japan? Because Japanese
culture respected ritual, precision, and
aesthetics. They had a growing interest
in western lifestyle.
It was the perfect mix of tradition and
modernism.
In 1996, Starbucks opened its first
store outside the US in Tokyo. And guess
what? It was an overwhelming success.
People stood in lines. It became a
fashion statement and it set the tone
for future global expansion.
After Japan came, UK, China, Singapore,
South Korea, United Arab Emirates,
Germany, and dozens more. By the end of
the 1990s, Starbucks was in over 20
countries. As Starbucks grew, so did the
numbers. By 1997,
1400 stores. By 1999, 2500 plus stores.
Annual revenue over $1 billion. Howard's
net worth over a hundred million. But
along with success came new challenges.
When you grow from one store to 2500 in
a few years, quality control becomes a
nightmare. Some problems started to
appear. Inconsistency.
Some stores felt warm and personal.
Others felt cold and robotic.
Overcrowding.
Stores became too busy. People
complained about long lines and noise.
Overstandardization.
The same colors, music, and design began
to feel too corporate. Howard felt
uneasy.
I didn't want to build McDonald's. I
wanted to build something meaningful.
But now, Wall Street was involved.
Shareholders wanted faster growth, more
stores, higher profits.
Howard was now in a tugofwar between
vision and velocity, between purpose and
pressure, between soul and scale.
At this point, Howard Schultz was not
just a CEO. He was managing thousands of
employees, overseeing global expansion,
dealing with investors, protecting
company culture. He was exhausted.
In 2000, after building Starbucks for
nearly 20 years, Howard made a shocking
announcement. He was stepping down as
CEO.
Howard said, "I've taken the company as
far as I can. Now it's time for someone
else to take it higher."
He stayed as chairman, but gave
day-to-day leadership to Orin Smith and
later Jim Donald. The new leaders
focused more on growth, stock prices,
and systems. And at first, it worked.
Stores kept opening, profits kept
growing, stock prices kept rising. But
something else was growing too.
Disconnection. Howard would later say,
"I walked into some stores and I didn't
recognize them. They were clean, busy,
profitable, but something was missing.
The soul of Starbucks, that warm,
personal feeling was fading. By 2007,
cracks turned into shocks. The global
financial crisis hit. Consumers were
spending less. Critics began saying,
"Why pay $4 for coffee in a recession?"
Starbucks started closing stores,
cutting jobs, facing public criticism.
Its stock price dropped from $40 to $8,
an 80% crash. And suddenly, the company
that once felt invincible looked like it
might fall apart. Howard watched from
the sidelines, helpless, frustrated, and
heartbroken.
But he wasn't done yet.
Part three, the comeback of a broken
dream. It's 2008.
Starbucks is in trouble. The global
economy is falling apart. The world is
entering a financial crisis. People are
losing their jobs. Families are cutting
their spending. And suddenly, $4 coffee
no longer feels like a small treat. It
feels like a luxury they can't afford.
Sales drop. Customer visits fall, store
traffic slows. Starbucks, once a symbol
of modern culture, is now seen as
overpriced, overrated, overexpanded,
and the numbers are brutal. In one year,
the stock falls from $40 to under $8.
The company loses over 6 billion in
value. Store closures begin. Hundreds of
locations shut down. Thousands of
employees are laid off. morale collapses
inside the company. The magic is gone
and behind the scenes, one man is
watching.
Heartbroken,
Howard Schultz is no longer CEO. He
stepped down in 2000, but he remained
chairman, watching from a distance. He
visits stores and feels a sharp pain in
his chest. This is not what I built, he
whispers. He sees dirty floors,
distracted baristas, empty chairs,
customers who feel rushed and invisible.
Everything he stood for, connection,
experience, emotion, is fading fast. And
then one day, the board of directors
comes to him and says, "Howard, we need
you back." It's January 2008. Howard
Schultz, now 54 years old, steps back in
as CEO of Starbucks. But this time it's
different. He's not coming back to lead
a celebration.
He's coming back to save a dying dream.
And he knows the truth. This will be the
hardest fight of his life. The world is
in crisis. The media doubts him. The
company is collapsing. And worse, the
culture is broken. But Howard doesn't
hide. He steps in with fire in his eyes
and says to his team,
"We are not in the coffee business
serving people. We are in the people
business serving coffee and we've
forgotten that." Howard begins with
radical decisions.
One closes 900 stores. Yes, 900 stores
across the US and abroad are shut down.
Not because they didn't make money, but
because they didn't reflect the brand's
soul. Two, fires thousands of employees.
It breaks his heart, but he knows. If we
don't cut now, we may not survive.
Three, halts all new store openings.
Growth is paused. Focus returns to
quality. Four, cuts his own salary. He
reduces his annual salary to $1 to send
a message.
This is not about me. This is about
saving us. Five. Retrains every single
barista. Howard shuts down all 7,000
stores in the US for one day. It costs
millions of dollars in lost revenue. But
to him, it's worth it. That day, every
Starbucks partner goes through espresso
retraining. Howard says, "We're not just
fixing technique. We are bringing back
pride."
Howard focuses on restoring the magic.
Better espresso machines for consistency
and flavor. No more microwaved
sandwiches. The smell ruined the coffee
aroma. More focus on eye contact,
conversation, personalization,
redesigning stores, making them feel
like real third spaces again. He also
introduces new ideas. Free Wi-Fi in all
locations.
mobile ordering for faster service, the
Starbucks Rewards app, which becomes one
of the most successful loyalty apps in
the world. Howard also begins to shift
Starbucks into a force for good. He
increases investment in fair trade
coffee, supporting small farmers in
Latin America and Africa, ethical
sourcing, ensuring farmers are paid
fairly, sustainability,
reducing waste, promoting recycling,
diversity and inclusion, hiring more
veterans, minorities, and refugees.
He says success is empty if you're not
lifting others with you. And Starbucks
becomes more than a coffee company
again. It becomes a brand that stands
for something bigger. By 2010, the world
sees something incredible.
Starbucks rises again. Here are the
results. Revenue climbs back to 11.7
billion. Net income grows to $946
million. Stock price recovers to over
30. Customer traffic increases. Employee
satisfaction rises. Brand trust is
restored. From Wall Street to Main
Street, people say the same thing.
Howard Schulz saved Starbucks.
But more than numbers, something else
returns. The aroma of real coffee, the
sound of soft music, the sight of
baristas smiling again, the energy of
connection inside stores. The Starbucks
experience is alive once more.
Howard walks into a store in Brooklyn,
not far from where he grew up. He sees a
young barista hand a cup to an old man,
smile, and say, "This one's on me today,
sir. You always brighten our day."
Howard smiles. That, he says, is what
it's all about. Part four, the final
cup. Legacy of a dreamer who never gave
up. It's 2017.
Starbucks has fully recovered. The brand
is stronger than ever. It has over
25,000 stores across the world, a market
value of over 80 billion, over 300,000
employees, one of the most recognized
logos on the planet, customers in more
than 70 countries, a stock price that
has grown by thousands of percent since
its IPO.
The Starbucks app is one of the most
used mobile payment platforms in the US,
even beating Apple Pay in some markets.
But more than numbers, Starbucks has
become a global habit, a part of
people's lives. From students to CEOs,
from Tokyo to Toronto, from Mumbai to
Miami, people walk in, speak their drink
out loud, and feel heard, seen, and
valued.
By now, Howard Schultz is in his early
60s. He often walks into stores quietly,
unannounced.
Sometimes he watches a single mother
working on her laptop, sipping a latte.
Sometimes he sees a homeless man being
handed a warm coffee by a smiling
barista. And sometimes he hears the
sound of laughter, music, and peace. and
he thinks
this is exactly what I dreamed of. Not a
product, a place, a feeling. He didn't
want to build the biggest coffee
company. He wanted to build the most
human. And he did. Let's pause for a
moment and look at the scale of what
Howard built. Metric then 1987.
Now 2017 stores 6 25,000 plus revenue 5
million year over 22 billion year
employees a few dozen over 300,000
countries one US over 70 stock price IPO
17 share over 60 share company value 250
million over 80 billion all this from a
man who grew up in public housing who
saw his father suffer and promised he'd
never let workers ers feel unseen again.
In 2017, Howard Schultz once again
stepped down as CEO, this time on his
own terms. He said, "It's time for a new
generation to lead, but I'm not leaving.
I'm just passing the torch."
He handed the leadership to Kevin
Johnson, a former tech executive and
longtime Starbucks board member.
Howard remained chairman, still
involved, still passionate, but no
longer in daily operations.
But Howard didn't retire to relax.
Instead, he turned his energy toward
social impact, human rights, veteran
employment, helping underserved
communities, fixing the American dream.
He launched initiatives to hire over
10,000 military veterans,
offer free college education to
Starbucks employees through
partnerships,
provide employment to refugees and
disadvantaged youth,
advocate for racial and economic equity.
Howard believed that companies have a
responsibility bigger than profit.
We are not in business to make money
alone.
We are in business to elevate humanity.
Most people don't know this, but
Howard's desire to care for employees,
build a warm company, and serve people
with dignity, came from personal pain.
His father, Fred Schulz, was a delivery
truck driver. One day, he slipped on ice
and injured his hip. He was fired. No
compensation, no support, no respect.
Howard was only 7 years old at the time.
He never forgot how his father sat at
home broken both in body and in spirit.
I saw what happens when workers are
invisible.
Starbucks became the answer to that
pain.
So he built a company where even a
part-time barista got healthcare, stock
options, education, and dignity.
In 2019, Howard announced he was
exploring a run for president of the
United States.
Why? Because he believed that leadership
meant service, not power. He wanted to
bring the same human first philosophy he
used at Starbucks into the political
world. Although he eventually dropped
the idea, the message was clear.
I was a poor kid from the projects. I
built something that touched the world.
So why not use that experience to heal
even bigger things.
Today, Howard Schultz is retired from
Starbucks, but the culture he built
still lives in. Every smiling barista,
every warm cup of coffee, every customer
who sits and feels at peace, every
employee who is called a partner, not a
worker. Every morning ritual that begins
with a name written on a cup. He turned
coffee into connection. He turned a
commodity into a community.
And he showed the world that you can
build a billion dollar company without
losing your soul.
What you can learn from Howard Schultz.
One, your past does not define your
future. A poor boy from the projects can
build a global brand. Two, rejection is
not the end, it's the beginning. Howard
was rejected two and 17 times before
someone believed in him. Three, lead
with your heart, not just your head.
Profit is important, but people are
everything.
Four, your business is your legacy.
Every decision you make leaves a mark on
someone's life. Five, success means
nothing if your people feel invisible.
Howard built a company to heal the pain
he saw in his father's eyes. Howard once
said, "Dream more than others think
practical. Care more than others think
wise.
Expect more than others think possible.
And don't be afraid to be the only one
who believes.
He believed. And because he believed,
today,
over 100 million people walk into
Starbucks stores every week. Not just
for coffee, but for comfort, connection,
and a small piece of hope.
And it all started with a boy who had
nothing except a dream and a reason to
never give up.
This is the end of the Starbucks story.
But this should be the beginning of your
story.
Maybe you have no money. Maybe your
family never believed in you. Maybe you
feel invisible. But remember this. If
Howard Schultz could do it, so can you.
Don't wait for permission. Don't wait
for comfort. Don't wait for the world to
clap. Start now. Build. Believe. Begin.
because your dream matters. And one more
thing, this story wasn't just about
coffee. It was about life, leadership,
love, and legacy. It was told in simple
English so that anyone anywhere in the
world can understand it and feel
inspired.
So if you learned something today, if
you felt something today,
then share it because maybe someone out
there needs to hear this story more than
you can imagine. Thank you for
listening.
Thank you for dreaming.
And thank you for believing.
